Description: Lower body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of bird to right (tail feathers, some in added red with dots in added white, and legs remaining); incised blob rosette and line as filling ornament; below, two sets of three bands; glaze at bottom.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The animal is probably a siren or griffin-bird.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 122, pl. XXXVII, no. 346.2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 230, no. 159)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.276) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4742 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
